body: I will come up with a solution, because the bug is starting to annoy me.

@MateiIonutEduard this issue refers to a bug introduced in in 7.0.0-preview.3 (or maybe even preview.4), and is not present in 6.0 - are you sure this is affecting you?

Either way, I plan to work on this soon, and it's not necessarily a good issue for an external contributor to work on (as I'm working in this area of the code at this moment).

issue.title: SQL Server: Possible off-by one in batch splitting logic

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
While investigating workarounds for https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore/issues/13617, I observed that the actual max number of parameters you can have in a `SqlCommand` is 2098 and not 2100 as I originally believed. It turns out that is because [`sp_executesql`](https://docs.microsoft.com/sql/relational-databases/system-stored-procedures/sp-executesql-transact-sql) takes two extra parameters: `@stmt`, for the SQL statement, and `@params`, which contains the definition of all parameters passed in `@stmt`. 

Looking at the code in 
https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore/blob/179a2ddaa922fdd123fb58216becdb980ef44999/src/EFCore.SqlServer/Update/Internal/SqlServerModificationCommandBatch.cs#L23
we consider that the max number is 2100, but in 
https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore/blob/179a2ddaa922fdd123fb58216becdb980ef44999/src/EFCore.SqlServer/Update/Internal/SqlServerModificationCommandBatch.cs#L25
we initialize the parameter count to 1, to account only for the parameter reserved for the command text. 

It is likely that the way we check with `>=` in 
https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore/blob/179a2ddaa922fdd123fb58216becdb980ef44999/src/EFCore.SqlServer/Update/Internal/SqlServerModificationCommandBatch.cs#L75
makes everything work correctly, but the code isn't clear and we expose some of these values outside of the class, so failing this issue to make sure there are not unintended consequences.

issue.title: EF7 preview: SaveChangesAsync with large number of changes leads to "DbUpdateException: The incoming request has too many parameters"

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
I am not sure if this is a bug and I have a hard time reproducing this behaviour in a demo environment, so I will formulate my problem as a question: What exactly has changed in the way ef constructs insert / update queries?

I have a bunch of import operations which are creating / updating a ton of entities. In the end, `DbContext#SaveChangesAsync` is called once, which always worked fine. 
Using the EF7 preview (7.0.0-preview.3.22175.1) however, `SaveChangesAsync` throws a `DbUpdateException` saying "The incoming request has too many parameters". Since no queries are constructed manually I have no Idea where the problem on my side could be. 
I suspected some problem with batchin and dug into ef itself. What I found is, that some of the batches created by `RelationalDependencies.BatchPreparer.BatchCommands(...)` in `RelationalDatabase#SaveChangesAsync` some of the commands have way more than the allowed 2100 parameters (defined by the azure database?). As far as I can tell all of those commands (ReaderModificationCommandBatch#StoreCommand) look similar to this:

```
MERGE [Table1] USING (
VALUES (@px, @py, .....)
....;
MERGE [Table2] USING (
VALUES (@pz, @pw, .....)
....;
```

i.e., consist of multiple MERGE commands with a total of 2500 parameters or more.

Is there anything I'm doing wrong with respect to changes in ef7 or is this i fact a bug in the CommandBatchPreparer?

rename.from: New batch size check doesn't take pending bulk insert commands into account
rename.to: Parameter check doesn't take pending bulk insert commands into account

issue.title: Fix bugs in SQL Server bulk insert management

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
For the parameter check, we previously added the parameters only when the pending bulk insert commands were applied; this is why they weren't being taken into account for the parameter limit check. The fix here is to move parameter adding to when the bulk insert command is added, just like any normal command; only the SQL addition is deferred.

Note that this won't support fancy bulk strategies, such as a single array parameter for multiple rows in PostgreSQL. But other things have to be done for that anyway, and this seems like an acceptable fix for now.

Fixes #27840
Fixes #28712

rename.from: Parameter check doesn't take pending bulk insert commands into account
rename.to: Parameter and SQL length check don't take pending bulk insert commands into account
